content.text: Define acceleration
graph A
graph B
graph C
graph D
Fig. 1.1 shows two speed–time graphs, A and B, and two distance–time graphs, C and D
Describe the motion shown by:
Calculate the mass of the sea water in the container
The atmospheric pressure is \(100 \text{kPa}\) and the total pressure on the top surface of the submarine is \(500 \text{kPa}\)
Calculate the depth of the top surface of the submarine below the surface of the sea
A hatch (an opening door) on the top surface of the submarine has an area of \(0.62 \text{m}^2\)
Calculate the downward force on the hatch due to the total pressure on the top surface of the submarine
Fig. 2.1 shows a submarine. The submarine is fully submerged in the sea
A scientist fills a container with sea water. The container has dimensions \(30 \text{cm} \times 30 \text{cm} \times 40 \text{cm}\). The density of sea water is \(1020 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\)
Fig. 3.1 shows a double-decker bus on a tilted platform
The platform is used to test the stability of the bus
The angle the bus makes with the horizontal is gradually increased until the bus begins to topple to the left
Explain why the bus begins to topple
There are 30 passengers in the upper compartment of the bus and 2 passengers in the bottom compartment of the bus
State how this affects the stability of the bus and the reason for this
Calculate the total mass of the bus, the driver and the 73 passengers
The fully loaded bus accelerates uniformly from rest to a speed of \(14 \text{m/s}\). The time taken to reach a speed of \(14 \text{m/s}\) is \(20 \text{s}\)
Calculate the resultant force on the bus during the acceleration

A bus is travelling along a straight road. The bus and the driver have a combined mass of \(16 000 \text{kg}\) when there are no passengers in it. The bus has 73 passengers. The average mass of each of the passengers is \(65 \text{kg}\)
In a double-decker bus there are two passenger compartments, one above the other
Describe, in terms of molecules, what happens when a liquid evaporates
Fig. 4.1 shows wet clothes drying on a washing line in an outside area
State **two** changes in the weather that help the wet clothes to dry more quickly
Calculate the energy supplied by the heater
Calculate a value for the specific heat capacity of the sand, using your answer to (a)(i) and the data in the question
specific heat capacity =   .........
Explain why the specific heat capacity of sand may be different from the value calculated in (a)(ii)
Fig. 5.1 shows a plastic cup. The cup contains sand, an electric heater and a thermometer

The power of the heater is \(50\mathrm{W.}\) The mass of the sand in the cup is \(550\mathrm{g.}\) The initial temperature of the sand is \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C.}\) The heater is switched on for 2.0 minutes. The temperature is recorded until the temperature stops increasing. The highest temperature recorded by the thermometer is \(33^{\circ}\mathrm{C.}\)
On a sunny day, the temperature of the sand on a beach is much higher than the temperature of the sea
Explain why
Draw a labelled diagram to show the structure of a thermocouple thermometer
Fig. 6.1 shows crests of a sound wave after reflection from a solid surface
solid surface
On Fig. 6.1, draw **three** crests of the incident wave
Tick **four** statements in the list below that are **false** for a sound wave that is audible to a healthy human ear
The wave is longitudinal
The wave is transverse
The frequency of the wave is \(1\mathrm{Hz}\)
The frequency of the wave is \(1\mathrm{kHz}\)
The frequency of the wave is \(1\mathrm{MHz}\)
The wave travels in a vacuum
The wave could travel in aluminium
State a typical value for the speed of a sound wave in water
The refractive index of diamond is 2.42
Calculate angle \(x\)
Explain the term total internal reflection
The angle \(y\) is greater than the critical angle of diamond
On Fig. 7.1, draw the path of the red light through and out of the prism after point A.
Fig. 7.1 shows red light travelling from air into a prism made of diamond. The path of the red light is incomplete
Fig. 7.1 (not to scale)
Describe what is meant by an _electric field_
State what is meant by the _direction_ of an electric field
Fig. 8.1 shows a polystyrene ball covered with aluminium paint. The polystyrene ball is suspended between two charged metal plates by an insulated thread
The ball oscillates between the two charged plates
Explain why the ball oscillates
There is a current of \(0.29\mathrm{A}\) in an electrical circuit
Calculate the time taken for a charge of \(15\mathrm{C}\) to flow through the electrical circuit
On Fig. 9.1, draw a pair of arrows to show which way the coil rotates. Explain the direction you have chosen
On Fig. 9.1, draw an arrow to show the direction in which electrons flow through the coil
Explain why the electrons flow in the direction you have shown in (a)(ii)
changing the polarity of the power supply to that shown in Fig. 9.2
changing the coil to the new coil shown in Fig. 9.3
using a stronger magnetic field
State any difference each of the following changes makes to the rotation of the coil in Fig. 9.1:
Fig. 9.1 shows a simple direct current (d.c.) electric motor. The coil rotates about the axis when there is a current in the coil. The coil is connected to the rest of the circuit by the brushes
A radioactive nucleus of carbon decays to a nucleus of nitrogen by emitting a particle
Complete the nuclide equation and state the name of the particle
name of particle X
Explain why the radiation detector records a reading and suggest a possible source
explanation
source
Carbon-14 has a half-life of 5700 years. There are atoms of carbon-14 in all living organisms

An archaeologist digs up some ancient wood. In the same laboratory as in **(b)(i)**, a sample of this ancient wood gives a reading of 20 counts/min. An equivalent sample of living wood gives a reading of 80 counts/min. It is suggested that the age of the ancient sample is 11400 years
Do a calculation to check whether this suggestion is correct
A radiation detector in a laboratory records a reading of 10 counts/min. There are no radioactive samples in the laboratory
